name: transport, freight train, steam | transport, freight train | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/23133/documentation

Based on Chinese railway steam freight transport. Inventory refers to the entire transport life cycle. For rail infrastructure, expenditures and environmental interventions due to construction of roads have been allocated based on the gross tonne kilometre performance in Europe.

The dataset starts with the production of a locomotive.

Based on Chinese railway freight transport; it includes operation of steam train only. This dataset calls the modules 'production, maintenance of vehicles'; 'construction of railway tracks'.
category: H:Transportation and storage/49:Land transport and transport via pipelines/491:Transport via railways/4912:Freight rail transport

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Extrapolated from "transport, freight train, stream, CN 2004"
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: see Geography/Text This dataset has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography CN. The uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.

flow.name: transport, freight train
flow.category: H:Transportation and storage/49:Land transport and transport via pipelines/491:Transport via railways/4912:Freight rail transport

exchanges.description: Estimated value. Emissions from the steam locomotive have been roughly estimated adjusting the emission rates (per MJ) from “hard coal, burned in coal mine power plant (CN)” by the average LHV (24 MJ/kg bituminous coal assumed to be used for locomotives vs. 12 MJ/kg poor quality coal for small power plants). Additionally, to somewhat take into account the less efficient combustion characteristics, emissions rates have been modified upwards using a factor 2 greater than the, corresponding ones (per MJ) from a small power plants. Energy use and operation emissions

Estimated value. Emissions from the steam locomotive have been roughly estimated adjusting the emission rates (per MJ) from “hard coal, burned in coal mine power plant (CN)” by the average LHV (24 MJ/kg bituminous coal assumed to be used for locomotives vs. 12 MJ/kg poor quality coal for small power plants). Additionally, to somewhat take into account the less efficient combustion characteristics, emissions rates have been modified upwards using a factor 2 greater than the, corresponding ones (per MJ) from a small power plants. Energy use and operation emissions

Estimated value. The steam locomotive dataset is modelled in first approximation by assuming a factor of 4 in fuel (equivalent) utilization compared with a diesel locomotive, based on consideration of likely actual efficiencies (mix of first generation steam locomotives with typical drawbar thermal efficiency of approximately 7% and some second generation with superheating with efficiency up to 15%). Further correction has been applied using the factor 2.67. Energy use and operations emissions

flow.name: hard coal
flow.category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

defaultProvider.name: market for hard coal | hard coal | Cutoff, U
defaultProvider.category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

exchanges.description: Estimated value. Emissions from the steam locomotive have been roughly estimated adjusting the emission rates (per MJ) from “hard coal, burned in coal mine power plant (CN)” by the average LHV (24 MJ/kg bituminous coal assumed to be used for locomotives vs. 12 MJ/kg poor quality coal for small power plants). Coal for steam locomotives has a presumably lower ash content (say approximately 25% of coal weight) compared with coal for small coal mine plants (up to 50% of coal weight (Dones et al. 2003)), the retention efficiency is likely lower. Considering also that these locomotives are used mostly within Coal Bureaus, therefore in already highly polluted areas, and that pictures of some steam locomotive show dark and abundant plumes, the PM emission is likely high. Due to the assumptions on ash content, the disposal of ashes has been halved for the locomotive compared to small plants. Energy use and operation emissions

Estimated value. Emissions from the steam locomotive have been roughly estimated adjusting the emission rates (per MJ) from “hard coal, burned in coal mine power plant (CN)” by the average LHV (24 MJ/kg bituminous coal assumed to be used for locomotives vs. 12 MJ/kg poor quality coal for small power plants). Additionally, to somewhat take into account the less efficient combustion characteristics, emissions rates have been modified upwards using a factor 2 greater than the, corresponding ones (per MJ) from a small power plants. Energy use and operation emissions

Estimated value. Emissions from the steam locomotive have been roughly estimated adjusting the emission rates (per MJ) from “hard coal, burned in coal mine power plant (CN)” by the average LHV (24 MJ/kg bituminous coal assumed to be used for locomotives vs. 12 MJ/kg poor quality coal for small power plants). Coal for steam locomotives has a presumably lower ash content (say approximately 25% of coal weight) compared with coal for small coal mine plants (up to 50% of coal weight (Dones et al. 2003)), the retention efficiency is likely lower. Energy use and operation emissions

exchanges.description: Estimated value. Emissions from the steam locomotive have been roughly estimated adjusting the emission rates (per MJ) from “hard coal, burned in coal mine power plant (CN)” by the average LHV (24 MJ/kg bituminous coal assumed to be used for locomotives vs. 12 MJ/kg poor quality coal for small power plants). Additionally, to somewhat take into account the less efficient combustion characteristics, emissions rates have been modified upwards using a factor 2 greater than the, corresponding ones (per MJ) from a small power plants. Energy use and operation emissions

Estimated value. Additionally, to somewhat take into account the less efficient combustion characteristics, emissions rates have been modified upwards using a factor 2 greater than the, corresponding ones (per MJ) from a small power plants. Energy use and operation emissions

exchanges.description: Estimated value. Emissions from the steam locomotive have been roughly estimated adjusting the emission rates (per MJ) from “hard coal, burned in coal mine power plant (CN)” by the average LHV (24 MJ/kg bituminous coal assumed to be used for locomotives vs. 12 MJ/kg poor quality coal for small power plants). Additionally, to somewhat take into account the less efficient combustion characteristics, emissions rates have been modified upwards using a factor 2 greater than the, corresponding ones (per MJ) from a small power plants. Energy use and operation emissions

Estimated value. Emissions from the steam locomotive have been roughly estimated adjusting the emission rates (per MJ) from “hard coal, burned in coal mine power plant (CN)” by the average LHV (24 MJ/kg bituminous coal assumed to be used for locomotives vs. 12 MJ/kg poor quality coal for small power plants). Coal for steam locomotives has a presumably lower ash content (say approximately 25% of coal weight) compared with coal for small coal mine plants (up to 50% of coal weight (Dones et al. 2003)), the retention efficiency is likely lower. Considering also that these locomotives are used mostly within Coal Bureaus, therefore in already highly polluted areas, and that pictures of some steam locomotive show dark and abundant plumes, the PM emission is likely high. Due to the assumptions on ash content, the disposal of ashes has been halved for the locomotive compared to small plants. Energy use and operation emissions

Estimated value. Emissions from the steam locomotive have been roughly estimated adjusting the emission rates (per MJ) from “hard coal, burned in coal mine power plant (CN)” by the average LHV (24 MJ/kg bituminous coal assumed to be used for locomotives vs. 12 MJ/kg poor quality coal for small power plants). Energy use and operation emissions

Estimated value. Additionally, to somewhat take into account the less efficient combustion characteristics, emissions rates have been modified upwards using a factor 2 greater than the, corresponding ones (per MJ) from a small power plants. Energy use and operation emissions

exchanges.description: Estimated value. The steam locomotive dataset is modelled in first approximation by assuming a factor of 4 in fuel (equivalent) utilization compared with a diesel locomotive, based on consideration of likely actual efficiencies (mix of first generation steam locomotives with typical drawbar thermal efficiency of approximately 7% and some second generation with superheating with efficiency up to 15%). Further correction has been applied using the factor 2.67. Energy use and operations emissions
